intro: Acilepis nayarii, commonly known as the Mexican sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Mexico. It belongs to the family Scrophulariaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to thrive in dry, hot environments. Its leaves are often narrow and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. Acilepis nayarii is an important component of local ecosystems, providing nectar for pollinators and contributing to biodiversity in its native habitat.
